data.sampled: This appears to be an "iron condor" options trading strategy. It involves selling one out-of-the-money (OTM) put and buying another OTM put with a lower strike price; and selling one OTM call and buying another OTM call with a higher strike price. The goal is to collect premium from both puts and calls while limiting potential losses if either underlying stock moves outside the range created by the sold options.

data.sampled: This appears to be an example of a bearish vertical spread option strategy. A bearish vertical spread involves selling and buying options with different exercise prices but the same underlying asset and expiration date. In this case, the trader has sold one put option with an exercise price of $390 (strike price) for $7.86 per share, bought another put option with an exercise price of $385 for $6.1 per share, sold one call option with an exercise price of $390 for $9.03 per share, and finally bought another call option with an exercise price of $395 for $6.2 per share. The difference between the sale price of each option and its corresponding purchase price represents the net credit received or debit paid by the investor for implementing this strategy.

data.sampled: The option strategy you described can be classified as a "bear spread." This type of strategy involves selling options at a higher strike price and buying options at a lower strike price to capitalize on an expected decline in the underlying asset's value. In this case, both puts have a net credit received from selling the calls, which means they have a positive time decay component (theta). As long as the stock does not move above $104 or below $98 before expiration, the trader will keep the premium collected, making it a low-risk strategy that benefits from volatility decrease (vega) if the underlying price stays stable around current levels.
